doc.after: According to the standard model in which a monopolist sets a single price for all consumers the monopolist will sell a lesser quantity of goods at a higher price than would companies by perfect competition Because the monopolist ultimately forgoes transactions with consumers who value the product or service more than its cost monopoly pricing creates a deadweight loss referring to potential gains that went neither to the monopolist nor to consumers Given the presence of this deadweight loss the combined surplus or wealth for the monopolist and consumers is necessarily less than the total surplus obtained by consumers by perfect competition Where efficiency is defined by the total gains from trade the monopoly setting is less efficient than perfect competition citation needed
